contentrichtext.text: '''Heinrich Wilhelm Schott''' (7 January 1794 in [[Brno|Brünn (Brno)]], [[Moravia]] – 5 March 1865 at [[Schönbrunn Palace]], [[Vienna]]) was an [[Austrian Empire|Austrian]] [[botanist]] well known for his extensive work on [[aroid]]s (Family [[Araceae]]). He studied [[botany]], [[agriculture]] and [[chemistry]] at the [[University of Vienna]], where he was a pupil of [[Joseph Franz von Jacquin]] (1766–1839). He was a participant in the [[Austrian Brazil Expedition]] from 1817 to 1821. In 1828 he was appointed ''Hofgärtner'' (royal gardener) in Vienna, later serving as director of the Imperial Gardens at Schönbrunn Palace (1845). In 1852 he was in charge of transforming part of palace gardens in the fashion of an [[English garden]]. He also enriched the Viennese court gardens with his collections from [[Brazil]]. He was interested in [[Alpine plants|Alpine flora]], and was responsible for development of the [[Alpinum (garden)|alpinum]] at [[Belvedere, Vienna|Schloss Belvedere]] in Vienna. {{botanist|Schott|Schott, Heinrich Wilhelm}} == Publications == * ''Meletemata botanica'' (with [[Stephan Ladislaus Endlicher]]), 1832 * ''[[Rutaceae]].
